topic.title: Configure Cluster Settings
topic.shortdesc: The Settings menu sets the global settings for your Couchbase Server instance.

body.p: Full Administrators and Cluster Administrators can configure cluster settings.
Use the Settings > Cluster tab to configure the cluster name, memory quotas, and index settings. You can define the settings using the Web Console, with the CLI command, or using the REST API.
To configure cluster settings using Couchbase Web Console:

ol.li: Select the Couchbase Web Console > Settings menu. By default, the Cluster page is displayed.
Enter the following settings and click Save:

row.entry: The name that was given during the initial setup. You can change it at any time.

section.title: Couchbase Memory Quotas
section.p: The per-node memory that is available to Couchbase services limited to the smallest node in the cluster. These values can be adjusted in the UI, with the CLI or with the REST API.

row.entry: The per node memory allocation for the key-value cache used by the data service. At a minimum, it cannot be made smaller than the sum per node bucket quota of all buckets combined.

This setting controls the buffer cache size of the index storage layer. The specified memory is pre-allocated as soon as the indexer starts up, and is shared with all indexes created on the node. The total memory usage of the indexer process will be the buffer cache plus the size of various internal data structures and queues.
This setting controls the RAM quota for Full Text search. It shows the amount of the main memory allocation for Full Text service per node.
This setting controls the RAM quota for Analytics. It shows the amount of the main memory allocation for the Analytics service per node.
This setting controls the RAM quota for Events. It shows the amount of the main memory allocation for the Events service per node.

section.title: Query Temp Disk Path
section.p: The path to which temporary files are written, based on query activities. Specify a maximum size in megabytes.

section.title: Log Redaction Level
section.p: Specify either None or Partial Redaction. Specifying Partial Redaction means that when explicit logging is performed by the user, user data, such as key/value pairs and usernames, will be redacted from the log files, during collection. Metadata and system data will not be redacted. Specifying None means that no redaction whatsoever occurs.

The setting established here constitutes the future default: therefore when the Collect Information screen is accessed for the purpose of explicit logging, the screen's user interface, in its initial appearance, inherits this setting. For more information on log redaction, including the location of log files and the performance of explicit logging, see Logging.

section.title: Advanced Index Settings for Standard and Memory-Optimized Indexes
section.p: Define the Global Secondary Index type as Standard or Memory-Optimized option and then click Show Advanced Index Settings pull-down menu.

row.entry: The number of dedicated threads used by the Index Service. The number can be increased on multi-core machines to increase the amount of CPU available to the Indexer. The default is set to 0.
The maximum number of the committed rollback points. The default is set to 5.

Adjust the logging level from least to most verbose, the options are: Silent, Fatal, Error, Warn, Info, Verbose, Timing, Debug, and Trace. The default is set to Info. It is advised to leave this setting as the default unless Couchbase Support directs you to change it.
